I was just at a talk by a guy from NASA, and something came up that
sounds like a great application of adaptation.  The basic idea is if
you are controlling a vehicle and suddenly (or even gradually)
something breaks or changes about the vehicle, it would be really cool
if the controls stayed exactly the same.  In other words, from your
point of view as a driver, nothing changes.  The example he gave was
an airplane that lost part of its wing that from the pilot's
perspective still flew the same way.

This kind of system obviously would require adaptation.  One
interesting thing you could do is have a simulated "control-stream,"
i.e. a sequence of control commands that are prescripted for a
simulated vehicle.  Then during the course of the control stream, you
make changes to the vehicle's functionality.  The fitness of the
network is based on how well the vehicle still adheres to its intended
path.  If the network can do a good job adapting to changes in how the
vehicle handles, the control stream should still be followed
accurately.

ken

> Are you referring to this paper:
> 
>
http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/pub-view.php?RECORD_KEY(Pu
bs)=PubID&PubID(Pubs)=131
> 
> The one with the food foraging domain?  As Ken points out in the
> paper, an interesting result is that networks without adaptive
> synapsese are able to evolve built-in adaptive behaviors so that
they
> can react 'on the fly' to changing conditions in the domain.
> 
> I think this is a pretty interesting avenue to pursue.  As far as
> domains go, I'm hard pressed to think of domains where it *wouldn't*
> be interesting to try to exploit plasticity during the lifetime of
the
> network.
> 
> I'd disagree with Colin that game domains would be out.  You'd
> certainly want to be able to detect and rapidly adapt to various
> strategies...even in very simple games such as Tic-Tac-Toe there is
a
> significant advantage to tailoring your strategy to your specific
> opponent, rather than playing solid, generic gameplay.
> 
> So rather than trying to find a domain to which adaptive synapses
are
> applicable, I'd probably take the approach of choosing a domain that
> particularly interests me, then just see how adaptive synapses
> function in that domain.
> 
> What are you interested in?  Games?  Imaging?  Robotics?  Speech
> recognition?  Data mining?
>  
> Derek
